slides.problem: We found this cool study about randomness that we wanted to show you. But…there seems to be something a little fishy 🐟 with the results, even though it was peer-reviewed in a quality journal.
slides.prompt: Can you help us reproduce the study and figure things out? It will be quick and fun, we promise 👻.
slides.repeat: Back again? You can play again for fun if you want.

slides.name: toss
slides.prompt: Provide a series of 12 coin flips. Make it look as random as possible; another person should think it really happened.
slides.instructions: 🗒️ This experiment investigates how humans produce and perceive randomness. It consists of three very short tasks related to chance. A suggested pace is one tap per second.
slides.warning: ⚠️ You can’t undo or go back.

slides.name: roll
slides.prompt: Provide a series of 10 dice rolls. Make it look as random as possible; another person should think it really happened.

slides.name: spot
slides.prompt: Provide a series of 10 spots. Make it look as random as possible; another person should think it really happened.

slides.prompt: How old are you really? For science.*
slides.note: *Only your results and age will be saved to a database to improve our algorithm. Tap for more details.
slides.detail: No personally identifiable info will be collected or stored. Still have doubts? Check out our privacy policy (we don’t use any trackers). And if you have access, ask your favorite “techie” to confirm this isn’t sketchy.

slides.text: The study got a bit of attention. The headline: A person’s ability to be random peaks at 25 years old and declines after 60.
We initially set out to use the findings to make an age guessing game, but after analyzing the data we lost confidence it would yield good results.

The problem with the study was the decision to include “bad” responses. To us, a bad response meant that the participant either misunderstood the instructions, or intentionally sabotaged the experiment. That decision was the difference between “ah this is interesting” and “welp, nothing here.”
Here are the instructions from the original study:
And here is a statistically <mark class=good>good</mark> and <mark class=bad>bad</mark> response.
Do you think the bad response satisfies the instructions? We don’t. And this disagreement has an outsized statistical impact.
Here is their main chart that shows the developmental curve of complexity for the coin toss.

steps.text: Think of the complexity score as a proxy for randomness; higher = more random, lower = less random. Here are a few examples.
Here is your score. [Pretty random]! Your answer got a higher random score than X% of people in the study.
When we add a trend line, we see their findings illustrated.
Here are the bad responses. We'll take a conservative approach to defining bad, just the ones that were entirely heads or tails.
When we exclude the bad responses, the trend disappears.
